description: Electric and magnetic fields; Coulomb's, Ampere's, and Faraday's laws; Maxwell's equations; emission, propagation, and absorption of electromagnetic radiation; interference, reflection, refraction, scattering, and diffraction phenomena.
name: PRINCIPLES II

values.comments:
The topics of this calculus-based course are electric and magnetic fields; Coulomb's, Ampere's, and Faraday's laws; Maxwell's equations; emission, propagation, and absorption of electromagnetic radiation; interference, reflection, refraction, scattering, and diffraction phenomena.

Overall, students found this course to be very difficult and a lot of work, but very worthwhile because they felt that the material was “relevant to things we see everyday.” This made the extra work not a waste of time.   One student noted that it was a “science course I’ve learned the most… from this far.”  

Students overwhelmingly had very positive reviews of Professor Sako.  The majority agreed that Professor Sako was a “great professor.”  Some even went so far as to describe him as “the best professor of physics at this university” and the “most amazing professor ever.”  Students also said Professor Sako was “extremely clear and communicates well.”  Professor Sako was extremely passionate about the material, “explaining the topics thoroughly and doing everything in his power to help his students excel.”  Students felt he not only was a great lecturer, but also “truly cares about his students.”

Students did not highly recommend this course for non-majors.  Students felt that the course was “manageable with hard work,” but one student felt it was “extremely difficult to keep up with the coursework.”  PHYS 150 or PHYS 170 is a prerequisite for this course.

This course covers electric and magnetic fields; Coulomb's, Ampere's, and Faraday's laws; Maxwell's equations; emission, propagation, and absorption of electromagnetic radiation; interference, reflection, refraction, scattering, and diffraction phenomena.

	Students did not generally like this course. Though some found the information to be interesting, many were taking the course just to fulfill a requirement. The material was considered difficult and the lectures unhelpful.

	Professor Reese was generally regarded by the students as inexperienced and ineffective at teaching a big lecture. This was widely attributed to Professor Reese being a new postdoc teaching a big lecture for the first time. Professor Reese was described by several students as “a good guy” and “very friendly,” as well as possessing an obvious command of the subject matter. Students said that Professor Reese taught verbatim from the book and often lacked confidence in his teaching, though this improved somewhat over time. Several students remarked on Professor Reese’s trouble communicating the ideas to the class. A couple students noted Professor Reese’s availability, accessibility, and helpfulness in his “plethora of office hours.”

	Students in this course found it to be very difficult, especially for those who had more limited knowledge and previous background in E&M. Students said that they were expected to “have a high understanding of E&M” and found it difficult to compete with those who had previously taken similar classes. The pace of topics covered was found to be challenging, with a pace of about one chapter per week. Most of the students taking the class were taking it for a requirement.
